project.name: gcloop
project.description: This project develops gcloop kernel module and userspace tools, which will be used to build official Gentoo LiveCDs
project.longdescription: This project develops gcloop kernel module and userspace tools, which will be used to build official Gentoo LiveCDs. The whole project aims to be completely compression algorithm agnostic, even if the current development is focused on ucl nrv2e compressor.

goals.p: The goal of the gcloop project is to provide a robust framework for building compressed partition image

body.p: Patches for 2.6 and 2.6-mm linux kernel: http://dev.gentoo.org/~lu_zero/gcloop/

First get the kernel patch an the userspace tools from http://dev.gentoo.org/~lu_zero/gcloop/ and the ucl lib from http://www.oberhumer.com/opensource/ucl/. Build and install ucl and then you can patch you kernel sources.
In order to use gcloop you have to set your .config in the following way
body.note: You can load both cryptoloop and compressloop or build them static, but you need a patched losetup.
body.p: To build the userspace tools you have just to type "make". Currently there are three different tools: two compressors and an unpacker/checker.

tr.ti: Quick and dirty compressor, it doesn't have many options and stores the whole compressed image in memory
Smarter compressor, it has some more options and stores the compressed image block by block, it could be slower
A simple unpacker that will output on stderr some statistics, usefull to access a gcloop image from a system without the kernel module and for checking the image consistency

body.p: Fist of all you need an uncompressed image, usually you can use dd and losetup to build it or mkisofs. After that you can use compress_gcloop_ucl to generate it.
body.pre: dd if=/dev/zero of=/tmp/image bs=1M count=700 mke2fs /tmp/image mount -o loop /tmp/myimage /mnt/data cp -pr /tmp/mydata /mnt/data umount /mnt/data compress_gcloop_ucl -c 10 -b 131072 /tmp/image /tmp/image.ucl
body.p: That is enough to build a compressed image

section.title: Verify and extract a compressed image

body.p: Once you built a compressed image you can use the extract_gcloop_ucl tool to verify the image in various ways. It will extract to stdout the image and outputs on stderr per block statistics. Errors will be notified with a short message.
A checksum program (like md5sum) could be useful for quick consistency tests.
The userspace tools can be compiled on every posix compliant environment. That way you can access the compressed image from foreing system
After building your modules you can mount a previously created gcloop image using a patched losetup. The patches for util-linux and busybox are available in the gcloop package.
body.pre: mkdir /mnt/image modprobe compressloop echo " "|losetup -E 19 -e ucl-0 -p0 /dev/loop0 /mnt/cdrom/image.ucl mount -o ro /dev/loop0 /mnt/image/
body.p: That is enough to read compressed image
